Award.AwardTitle: EAGER Collaborative Proposal: A microfluidic platform for the discovery of new, life-like chemical systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. David Baum and collaborators from the University of Wisconsin - Madison and Dr. David Eddington from the University of Illinois - Chicago to develop a microfluidic platform for the discovery of new, life-like chemical systems. There is a lack of knowledge about how new life-like chemical systems, having the capacity for reproducing and evolving, can emerge. The researchers are developing a device to screen complex chemical mixtures in order to find life-like systems that can grow over a mineral surface and can evolve more efficient growth over time. The goal of the project is the discovery of new life-like chemical systems, which would advance the understanding of how life originated on earth. The new experimental approach of this research is used to engage students and the public through presentations. It is also shared with diverse chemists, including high-school chemistry teachers, in a citizen-science effort to understand the nature of life's chemical origins.

This research project involves building a simple microfluidic device and an associated experimental paradigm for flowing a complex chemical mixture, in a stripe, over a mineral surface. This surface contains possible building blocks of autocatalytic cycles as well as inorganic or organic sources of energy. The stripe is displaced across the mineral surface over a multiple day experimental window. This experimental arrangement enables selection for adsorbed autocatalytic sets that can propagate themselves along the surface. Furthermore, if there is spatial variation in such autocatalytic systems, the device selects for variants that can more rapidly colonize newly encountered mineral. Among other analytical methods, X-ray photoemission spectroscopy is used to detect changes in the concentration of adsorbed carbon or nitrogen. Such changes would indicate an adaptive response to selection for enhanced colonization and growth. When new autocatalytic chemical systems are detected, their chemical composition is characterized.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award, aimed to develop a platform and experimental protocol for the discovery of new, life-like chemical systems. There is a lack of knowledge about how new chemical systems can emerge that are life-like, meaning that they have the capacity for self-propagation (growth) and adaptive evolution. We sought to deploy an artificial selection method in which (a) chemical systems that can nucleate and grow over a mineral surface are enriched, and (b) if multiple self-propagating variants are present, the most rapidly propagating systems would tend to predominate over time.  Our initial goal was to develop a microfluidic device that would allow us to quickly screen diverse chemical mixtures to find any that yielded systems with these life-like properties. It was hoped that this device would allow discovery of new life-like chemical systems, which would represent a great advance in our understanding of how life originated on earth and could open up new strategies for chemical engineering.

We aimed to try initial experiments using the mineral iron-pyrite, which has long been implicated as having had a role in the earliest origins of cellular metabolism. We were able to demonstrate a method to conduct these microfluidic experiments and also developed a new method to grow iron pyrite on a glass surface using microfluidic generation of hydrogen-sulfide. These advances, which may have diverse applications in the future, will be described in a journal paper. However, none of the microfluidic experiments yielded evidence of life-like chemical systems.

In parallel with the microfluidic research, we developed and prototyped a larger packed-bed flow reactor (PFR) that can be 3D-printed at low cost. We also developed a low-tech approach for selecting for propagating ability, which entailed incubating iron-pyrite grains and simulated prebiotic soups under low-oxygen conditions and repeatedly transferring small quantities of solutions and grains to vials with fresh reagents. One such experiment yielded compelling and statistically significant evidence of the emergence of a new life-like chemical system in selected lines (but not in controls). We are in the process of replicating this result and conducting more detailed analyses prior to submitted the results for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.

The laboratory work described stimulated two theoretical papers that were published by the principle investigator and contributed to the training of three graduate students and a large, diverse cadre of undergraduate research assistants.
